name: Brahma
shortDescription: The creator god of the Hindu Trimurti, who brings forth the universe from the cosmic waters
fullDescription: Brahma (Sanskrit: ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ, BrahmƒÅ) is the creator deity within the Hindu Trimurti (trinity), alongside Vishnu the Preserver and Shiva the Destroyer. Born from a golden lotus that emerged from Vishnu's navel, or in some accounts, self-manifested from the cosmic waters, Brahma is responsible for creating the universe and all living beings. He is typically depicted with four heads facing the four cardinal directions, symbolizing his omniscience and mastery over the four Vedas, and four arms holding various sacred objects including the Vedas, a water pot (kamandalu), a rosary (mala), and a lotus. His vahana (mount) is Hamsa, the sacred swan or goose. Brahma's consort is Saraswati, goddess of knowledge and arts. Despite being the creator, Brahma has relatively few temples dedicated to him in modern Hinduism‚Äîthe most famous being the Brahma Temple in Pushkar, Rajasthan. This paradox is explained by various myths, including one where Brahma was cursed by Shiva for speaking untruthfully, and another where Shiva cursed him for his arrogance. Brahma represents the creative principle (rajas), the cosmic architect who shapes reality from primordial chaos, and the limited role of creation in cyclical cosmology where preservation and destruction are equally vital.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Brahma's four heads symbolize omniscience and the four Vedas (Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, Atharvaveda), representing complete knowledge. The four arms represent the four directions and cosmic reach. The lotus he sits upon symbolizes purity emerging from the cosmic waters. His golden color represents sacred knowledge and creative fire. The water pot (kamandalu) symbolizes the cosmic waters from which creation emerges. The rosary represents time and the counting of cosmic cycles. His limited worship despite being creator reflects the Hindu philosophy that creation is only the beginning‚Äîpreservation and transformation (destruction) are equally vital to cosmic balance. Brahma represents limited creation‚Äîhe creates according to karma and cosmic law, not arbitrarily.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Brahma is central to Hindu cosmology as the creator god, yet paradoxically receives little worship compared to Vishnu and Shiva. The single major Brahma temple at Pushkar demonstrates his diminished cult status. This reflects the philosophical emphasis on cyclical time rather than linear creation‚Äîin an eternal, cyclical universe, initial creation is less significant than ongoing preservation and renewal. Brahma's day (kalpa) is said to last 4.32 billion years, during which he creates the universe, which is then dissolved during his night. Brahma represents the limitation of creative power‚Äîhe creates according to pre-existing karma and cannot override cosmic law. His association with Saraswati links creation to knowledge and learning.
